--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Stephen Waits <steve@...> wrote:
>
> 
> On Oct=
 5, 2007, at 5:46 PM, Derek James wrote:
> 
> > It's
> > the particular met=
hod of subdividing the population as a way of 
doing
> > it that I'm questi=
oning.
> 
> I wonder if, when creating NEAT, Ken tried using demes?  Where,=
 
each  
> deme has four neighbors, and migration (random or best) happens =
 
> occasionally between neighboring demes.  Edge demes wrap around 
(as  
=
> in a toroid).  This makes sense to me in a tribal sort of way.
> 
> Howev=
er, speciating on genome similarity also makes sense to me, 
but  
> in a s=
pecies sort of way.

I never tried what you call demes, or any kind of geog=
raphic-based 
mating structure.  I am guessing that it would not work badly=
 
because geophraphy tends to constrain local neighborhoods to similar 
ind=
ividuals and also because such schemes have been shown to work 
nicely in o=
ther contexts.  

However, there is an element of such considerations beyon=
d only 
performance in terms of conceptual elegance, and in that regard I 
=
prefer the network-topology-based speciation because it divides the 
popula=
tion based on the actually concept that supervenes their 
genetic relatedne=
ss, i.e. their topologies and weights.  The deme-
type distributed populati=
on introduces geography, which is not 
specifically tied into the nature of=
 the problem itself (whatever 
the problem may be), although it may implici=
tly do something 
similar, as may other methods.

As an empirical issue, ho=
wever, it would be interesting to try out.

ken
